Award.AwardTitle: The Madden Julian Oscillation, Tropical Cyclones, and Extratropical Circulation Responses
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will investigate the following: the extent to which observations and reanalyses of the extratropical outcomes associated with the Madden Julian Oscillation depend on the presence of tropical cyclones (TC) at different general geographical locations; whether different preferred extratropical outcomes occur during MJO events with or without tropical cyclones in many different general geographical regions; the relative impact on the predictability of the extratropical circulation associated with MJO events that include or do not include tropical cyclones in select geographical regions; the subsequent propagation patterns of MJO events that include or do not include TCs in particular initial states and the predictability of the MJO itself between different MJO initial states that include or do not include TCs in particular geographical regions. The research is focused on the Northwest Pacific basin and emphasizes the period September through October, when Northwest Pacific TCs are most frequent and MJO amplitude is often strong. Analysis of TCs in other basins will also concentrate on the 2-3 months of most intense TC activity there.

Results will provide insights that might benefit commodity and energy markets as well as disaster planners, some of whom already consider the MJO and northwest Pacific TCs in their assessments of future risks of extreme temperature and rainfall or drought events. Thus this activity has substantial broader impacts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Madden Julian osicllation (MJO) organizes rainfall into large eastward-moving regions in the tropics that typically take several weeks to move around the world. The MJO also influences the development and movement of tropical cyclones. Both tropical cyclones and the MJO cause waves to propagate through the atmosphere around the world, allowing these phenomena to influence global weather and extreme weather events. This project analyzed the relationships between the MJO, tropical cyclones, and global weather signals. The project confirmed earlier results that showed the average weather patterns that evolve in association with MJO events. These associated patterns are typically explained as if they are forced directly by rainfall patterns in the tropics associated with the MJO. Although that directly forced component is important, tropical cyclones interacting with the MJO can produce different weather patterns. Results showed that when tropical cyclones occur where the MJO favors them and not where it does not favor them, weather patterns are more likely to look more like those associated with the average MJO event at the given time of year. When tropical cyclones occur where the MJO does not favor them, the usual patterns are less likely to develop. Results explain why the differences emerge. The tropical cyclones act over relatively short periods of time in comparison with the MJO, but analysis of global weather data, using the atmospheric momentum equation, revealed that nonlinear terms in the equation yield signals on the same timescale as the MJO, thereby contributing additional signals associated with the MJO beyond those forced directly by the MJO itself. In regions where the MJO favors tropical cyclones, the patterns that develop in response to the cyclones develop in a larger number of MJO events, and so become part of the average weather pattern associated with the MJO. When tropical cyclones occur in more unusual places with respect to the MJO, the associated weather patterns tend to evolve differently from the average MJO event.

The results can inform weather forecasters about whether long range weather forecasts are likely to be disrupted by a tropical cyclone in a given geographical region during a given state of the MJO.
